instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-4924 no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message:
No liquid damage or drop damage, no previous work done on this Mac.
I get the appropriate light on the magsafe and it responds to SMC reset. No power to the machine though.

I checked PPBUS_G3H and get 0.686V at F7140

Also get:
PP3V42_G3H at C4850: 3.43v
PPVRTC_G3H at C1910: 3.43v
PP5V_S5 at C7505: 0.622v

Then I got to C7900 and C7901 which are both hot, sizzling hot, alcohol goes poof right away.

Second time I run into components getting this hot and it stops me as I don't want to do any/more damage. Any thoughts on where to go from here?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-4924 no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message:
They are on PPBUS, safe to rip them off and let be. Only 1 of them will be shorted, look closely at them and you can usually see a crack in the shorted one. 

You are VERY lucky with these easy fixes...

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-4924 no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message:
Hah you may have just jinxed me ;)
Easy fixes are nice but they don’t make for a great learning experience.

Will inspect closer and remove the culprit shortly.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-4924 no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message: No cracks in either, they actually look perfect (though that may have been the alcohol on it that cleaned them), still remove 'em?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-4924 no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message: If they are really the source of the heat and PPBUS is shorted then yes.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-4924 no power, responds to SMC reset
